name: Tirana
fun_fact: Fun fact: Tirana's buildings were painted in vibrant, clashing colors in 2000 by artist-mayor Edi Rama, who believed bright colors would lift citizens' spirits after decades of communist gray. The result is one of Europe's most colorful capitals where pastel pinks clash gloriously with electric blues.

hero_dishes.name: TavÃ« Kosi
hero_dishes.description: Tender lamb cooked in thick, tangy yogurt and egg mixture, baked until it forms a golden custard-like crust
hero_dishes.origin_story: This is Albania's national dish, traditionally served at weddings and celebrations. The name means 'soured milk casserole', and every Albanian grandmother has her own secret technique for getting the perfect golden crust
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Oda Restaurant (best in the capital), Juvenilja (Sunday lunch favorite)

hero_dishes.name: FÃ«rgesÃ«
hero_dishes.description: Delicious, slightly spicy cheese dip made with gjizÃ« (Albanian ricotta), roasted peppers, and tomatoes
hero_dishes.origin_story: This staple of Albanian households, especially in Tirana, delivers the perfect balance of peppers, tomatoes, and cottage cheese. It's comfort food that Albanians crave when living abroad
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Oda Restaurant, Mullixhiu (modern version), traditional restaurants in Pazari i Ri area

hero_dishes.name: Byrek
hero_dishes.description: Flaky, savory pie filled with spinach, ricotta cheese, meat, onions and tomatoes, or wild greens
hero_dishes.origin_story: While byrek has Ottoman origins, Albanians have made it their own with unique fillings and techniques. It's breakfast, lunch, or a snack - eaten at all hours from street vendors to fine restaurants
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mullixhiu (creative versions), street vendors around Pazari i Ri (New Bazaar), bakeries throughout the city

hero_dishes.name: Grilled Meat at Zgara
hero_dishes.description: Lamb, chicken, and pork grilled to perfection on the spit or over charcoal - simple but incredibly flavorful
hero_dishes.origin_story: Zgara means 'grill' in Albanian, and these grill houses are where locals gather for authentic, no-frills meals. It's Albanian cuisine at its most elemental and delicious
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Zgara Te Pazari (cheap, delicious, and authentic), numerous zgara restaurants throughout the city

signature_drinks.name: Raki
signature_drinks.description: Strong grape or plum brandy - the Albanian national spirit
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served as a welcome drink to guests (hospitality is sacred in Albanian culture) and consumed before meals as an aperitif. Every family has their own homemade version

signature_drinks.name: Albanian Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Strong, thick coffee similar to Turkish coffee, served in small cups

food_culture_notes: Oda Restaurant recreates traditional dishes exactly as Albanian grandmothers have made them for centuries, complete with live traditional music
Chef Bledar Kola at Mullixhiu worked at Copenhagen's famous Noma before revolutionizing Albanian cuisine with farm-to-table techniques
Eating out in Tirana is incredibly inexpensive - often cheaper than cooking at home
The New Bazaar (Pazari i Ri) is the heart of Tirana's food culture, recently renovated and buzzing with authentic flavors

atmosphere: blend of Ottoman and communist architecture
